column4: We had a wonderful time. It's a terrific way to spend as much or as little time outside walking as you want. There is a shorter loop if you prefer. It was a gorgeous day and we enjoyed it for 2 1/2 hours but that was taking our time. Don't miss it if you want to see the animals of...

With a 2 and 4 yr old we opted for the bus tour - well worth it! Not just to get a chance to see the whole preserve, but also for the guided tour. I didn't think we'd actually get to see some of the smaller animals and we did! Lynx and arctic fox as well as the larger animals....

A must when visiting Yukon. The tour bus guide was great. Had a lot of stories about their resident animals. Highly recommend a tour of the Yukon Wildlife Preserve by bus or just a leisurely walk around.
Visited last summer and it was cool to see some animals I've never seen before. It's great that they are helping animals

This is a great place to take your kids so they can learn about wildlife. The bus tour is really good. If you have small kids or younger kids who can't walk far, being a cart or stroller. It's a LONG, unmanageable walk for kids.

We had a private tour by Lindsay, who was wonderful in explaining the purpose of the centre and drove us to see the animals under their care. Thrilled to see the lynx, arctic fox, muskox among others.

We were able to do a mid-week "behind the scenes" tour to get closer to the animals they are rehabbing in addition to touring the grounds like the regular tour.Just seeing the wildlife up close makes this an interesting visit.Add to that the mission of trying to insure the species of the Yukon continue to be present in...
I love the animals. They look cared for and kept in great shape. The staff are knowledgeable and care deeply for the animals. Great family walk and in the summer a great bike ride as well.

Want to view Yukon wildlife only a short distance from downtown Whitehorse? Yukon Wildlife Preserve offers visitors views of fourteen or more species, ranging from elk, moose, bison, caribou, Arctic and red foxes, mountain goats and sheep, mule deer etcfrom the perspective of a gravel road that wends its way in a giant five kilometre figure eight past field,...

Temperature about -26C. Lots of game, some quite curious, others cautious but not extremely frightened. Bison, elk, caribou, musk oxen, mountain goats, fox, arctic fox, mountain and Dall sheep and lynx, moose,all within easy distance. 8km trail to follow and made an easy walk. Grades not difficult and the terrain changed substantially, suiting the animals well. Really enjoyed the refreshing...

We did a private bus tour with Who What Where Tours and it was great! The tour was about 2 hours I think, and we were able to take our time, not rushing at each location with each animal. It is very nice to see that each animal has a HUGE space to roam around, such as fields, and mountains...
It's 5km walk and it's also great for cross country skiiers! Saw lots of animals and they were amazing! Highly recommend
a little pricey for just a walk...beautiful scenery, and amazing wildlife....signage easy to follow and knowledgeable....

A wonderful way to see the animals in the most natural environment. The walk around the preserve was pretty easy even in ankle deep snow. We took some snacks to enjoy while taking in the scenery along the way on well positioned benches found all along the trail, which I recommend doing if travelling with children.
Great day BUT dress warm.........lots of open areas that allow the wind to pick up..........you want to spend a lot of time outside as the animals were active throughout our tour.

I reviewed the Preserve in August and again I'll give it a 5-Star for my winter visit. I went out there New Years day and though I failed miserably in dressing appropriately for the weather (I should know better as I live here!), it was still an exceptional day. I also invested in a year pass for $40. This is...

Loved our visit here! We walked by foot around the whole preserve, and loved seeing all the different wildlife. We went left around the loop, instead of right, and I'm so glad we did it that way as there's a hugh hill to climb UP instead of walk DOWN! :)

We went to the Yukon Wildlife Preserve with our tour company during the winter and enjoyed seeing the Canadian wildlife. All of the animals seemed happy and healthy in their enclosures and they were very adorable; especially the arctic foxes and lynx.

Certainly not the San Diego Zoo, but doesn't pretend to be. Does a great job of protecting local wildlife -- just not an exceptional tourist attraction. Only open on weekends during winter, so plan accordingly. And donate to their cause!
This place is a ery good opportunity to view wild animals. It`s not a zoo, so they are in their real environment.

We had Tina as our guide and she was fantastic, so knowledgable and friendly. The animals were beautiful and we got to see animals I didn't even expect to see, such as Arctic Foxes! Highly recommend to visit this preserve.

Begun when the owners wanted to divest themselves of a business for raising animals for hunting enthusiasts, this lovely and well maintained park is a great place to see indigenous animals and some from farther north like the arctic fox. The animals are healthy and well cared for, and some are very friendly and happy to pose. You and your...
We have a seasons pass and come up here all the time. My kids love seeing the animals and the animals are happy. Great place for them to bike.

Such a great preserve. The animals were about and were obviously well cared for. They are just as majestic in real life as they are in the photos. Our guide was very knowledgable about all of the animals and was very patient while waiting for some of them to make themselves know to us. High recommend.

This tour was recommended to us by our hosts at Northern Lights Resort and Spa and we were very glad we did it. It was almost the only wildlife we experienced on our White Christmas experience to BC, Alberta and Yukon.
I enjoy going to the Yukon Wildlife Preserve! Its a great place to learn about the northern wildlife. Whether you walk or take the bus tour there will be a smile on your face!

We visited as part of a 4 person tour group today (the park was closed otherwise). We got really lucky and were able to see every animal there so it must have been close to feeding time. So many beautiful views and the signs were all very informative.
We lucked out and despite the cold, saw a lot of animal activity (minus Caribou). If you love hitting up the local zoo when you travel or want to learn more about Arctic wildlife, I highly recommend!

I took the bus tour as it was a pretty cold day to be walking around. It was awesome to have a guide add some more detail and stories behind the history of the animals in the preserve and how they are breeding, caring for them, or how they came to be at the preserve. Great place to see some...

If you want to see the local animals then this is great. Private tour by extremely informative host Tina. Friendly and geeat to have a laugh with. Extremely accommodating of your needs. Only thing is a little pricey i thought.
This tour was quite interesting. Good organized. Nice place and after the wildlife preserve you can soak in the hot spring.

We were able to see lots of different animals which I haven't heard of before - Elk, Yak, Moose, Mountain Goats, Caribou to name a few. It was great seeing them in their natural habitat and how the government is trying to save these animals.
The Wildlife Preserve has a variety of animals from the Yukon that they care for, it is a beautiful walk and well worth the drive to do anytime of the year.
Excellent tour around the Preserve to see the native wildlife.Plenty of opportunity to photograph as well.
A excellent display of native animals in a natural environmentThe guide was very informativeThe research and veterinary services are of a very high qualityM wood

I didn't do the bus tour but I would absolutely recommend the walking tour. We went on a fairly cold day (-10 degrees Celsius) and it was just right with the right clothes.Almost every exhibit had the animals fairly close to the front so you could really see all of the animals fairly up close.

This trip was an amazing adventure! It was so interesting to see the native animals and their stories with interesting facts about each. The guides were very helpful in pointing out the hiding spots of each animal so we were able to see them all. What a beautiful place with plenty of space for the animals! Thanks Yukon for sharing...

Don't think of this place as the zoo you're used to. It's much, much bigger and offers a way to see Yukon Wildlife you may not otherwise see.Many of the animals were orphaned or injured and either can't be placed in the wild or are being rehabilitated. We took the small bus tour where you get out often to...
It's a beautiful place, the animals are in great condition, and even though they are behind fences, they have plenty of space to do as they likeThe mountain goat were my favorite!

The Yukon offers some unique sights. This is a place where you can experience and appreciated so much of what the Yukon has. The landscape is so dynamic and spectacular. The animals that you can see there are special and beautiful. Dress for the weather and you will love this spot.

Had a great time on the bus tour! Definitely worth the little extra money for the guidance as our tour guide gave us pelts to feel, pictures of x-rays of the animals to look at, and was able to tell us the animals' background stories!My favourite was the red fox who was first thought to be a dog and...

Very much surprised at how many animals were located here. They're in their native environment and with plenty of space to roam. There is a large area to cover, so plan on spending a couple of hours if you want to see and learn all about these animals. With the exception of the foxes, we saw Canada lynx, muskox, elk,...

Really nice preserve with a variety of animals to see. There were bus rides available, but we chose to walk through the preserve, and it was an excellent hike - not too strenuous, but a great way to get out and get moving!

We walked through this attraction today, in the snow. It was cold, but this was not a disadvantage. What we weren't impressed with was the disinterested approach of the lady on the desk. She was quite dismissive of us when we arrived and was so dismissive when we finished our walk it was insulting. The park itself is obviously doing...
A must see for anyone who comes to Whitehorse, we took the tour bus both times we went and also bought a family pass, guides are very friendly and knowledgeable
We walked rather than take the tour. Good walk, but the tour and guide would have been more helpful. Beautiful place.
The animals were easily accessible yet were living in their own environment. The tour guide, Maureen, was outstanding.

We spent two and a half hours on a self guided tour through the preserve. It was a bit of a chilly day but we bundled up and the animals were up and moving as well. We saw some pretty cool animals that unless you were deep into the Yukon wild you may not see on the normal day. There...

We had a lovely afternoon walking the grounds and viewing the wildlife. We can get quite close to the animals and have opportunity to watch them play around. We spend 3-4 hours walking around and watching the animals.
Great place with informative tour guide and great photo opportunities of animals and the surrounding landscapes.

There are many animals to see here and although they are fenced in with acres of land to roam we did get to see them close up as some are quite happy to wander over to the fence, especially the moose which was good. Geronimo the grumpy mountain goat turned his back on us as soon as we moved toward...

We travelled the whole of the Yukon looking for moose and saw none until here and also got to get a good close up look at such cuties as the mountain goat. They offer bus tours, but you can also do a self guided walk, which is flat and easy enough to do, but quite a distance. We don't do...

Our tour guide was informative and very helpful. We did a 12 noon tour, which was quieter than the 2pm tour. We were glad we saw a moose, the only one we saw on our month long holiday in Canada.A great way to spend a couple of hours.
Well worth the $20.00. The guide had a wealth of information about the animals. The bus ride around the preserve was comfortable and the people I interacted with were very friendly.

This is a beautiful place where an animal lover, and the photographer can leisurely walk and enjoy themselves. The animals all have beautiful pens that are open and very well thought out. Lots of room to move around . Great places to take photos too.

They offer walk-in and bus tours of their collection of rescued and site bred wildlife typical of the area. Animals are observable in very large fenced areas. Bus tour includes informative commentary on the origins and operation of the facility as well as information about their animals. They run a very successful breeding program for some of the areas endangered...

Yukon wildlife reserve is a bit outside the city however well worth it. My wife and I went here together. Give yourselves at least 2 hours to complete the walk in the park and 5-10 minutes to get tickets and get prepared to walk. 12 dollars per person to use the shuttle service was a few $ more however if...

If you are in Whitehorse you must visit the preserve. Performing fabulous rehabilitation work and boasting some of the most natural looking areas for wildlife in captivity. My favourite area is the moose enclosure. Just miraculous views and habitat for the moose to reside in.

The preserve has a wide variety of wildlife. You can walk the trail in about 2 hours or take the bus tour if you prefer. It was a beautiful sunny day so we walked. Lots of photographic opportunities. The animal enclosures are huge - these are NOT zoo cages - so large that you might only see the animals at...

A massive expanse of land for these majestic animals, take the guided tour and be driven around this vast preserve. They have Bison, Caribou, Moose, Deers, Elks, Mountain Goats, Spinx, Arctic foxes to name a few. We had a great afternoon.

WE really enjoyed seeing so many of the animals from the Yukon region in their natural habitat. You can do a bus tour or walk. We choose to walk so we could take our time and enjoy the beauty of the preserve and took many pictures

This game preserve is wonderful! You can walk the roads or take a bus with a knowledgable driver. A great chance to learn about and observe caribou, wood bison, moose, elk, mule deer, stone sheep and mountain goats. We were lucky enough to see the Lynx pair come out at feeding time and see Arctic foxes too! A must see...
Neat place. Loved the animals especially the puppies. Not an all day thing for us (two 25 year olds) but still appreciated it!

I signed up for a tour and when it turned out I was the only one there, I expected to be told to come back tomorrow. Instead I had a private tour with a knowing guide. I had close up looks at almost all of the animals on the site and learned quite a bit about the area.
The staff here are wonderful and extremely knowledgeable. We took the bus tour. I would love to walk it on my own but the bus guide was amazing and the tour made the visit.
It was amazing to see the animal running so free in this Preserve and not a zoo like. Animals are released back to the wild if possible.
We saw several species of animals, including mountain goats, bighorn sheep, moose, bison, reindeer, prairie dogs, elk, Arctic fox, and deer. A fun place, but photography is difficult due to fencing.

The guided tour around the preserve was excellent. The guide stopped at each wildlife area, explained about the animals, allowed plenty of time for pictures and questions.The preserve has 16 different species of animals right now. There is plenty of land so the animals seem to be in a good place.Great way to spend some time when in...

I went here to get a close up view of some northern animals. I did see some up close, but you may not see them all. You can walk it in about 2 hours, so wear comfortable shoes and bring extra layers of clothing. The scenery is nice too.
What a place . Seen so many animals . Great facility for animals:) we walked it, they do offer bus tours. We wish we would have brought bicycles:):):)
Love the way the animals have room and not caged in small enclosures. Lovely 5km walk around the park.
Great place to visit! There's a good variety of animals. The walk is about 5 km with some hills. You can walk, bike or take a tour. Lovely experience!!

This is a great place to see the wild life. The animals are used to having lots of people around so they don't get scared and run away. The mountain Rams are friendly enough that mywife could pet the ram's nose through the fence. Our guide was very informative and I loved her French accent.

I generally don't like zoos or animal preserves unless they exist to rehabilitate animals for the wild or house animals that can't be returned to the wild because of injuries. This preserve falls in the middle. The animals have large areas to roam in and are well taken care of.

This was a repeat visit in the first week of September during the lovely early falls days. The preserve is accessible for all and we chose to walk around the full 5km to see the animals and enjoy the wonderful scenery in the sun. Lots of animals out and able to be seen without much trouble. Saw a wild red...
We did the walk around the reserve and it was great was a good walk with a few hills but the views were beautiful at the top! The animals are all great and the space they are in is wonderful!

We took the bus tour. Our guide Christiane was just excellent at talking about the various animals, their habits and habitats. The tour took almots 2 hours but weel worth it. Although you could probably see many of these in a zoo, this is more like their natural habitats--over 700 acres. The number of species may be limited but some...

This is a great way to see some classic Canadian animals on the large preserve. I did the self guided walking tour and took my time - walked the whole thing and it took about 2.5 hours. Some animals are easier to see than others but the fun is looking for them - waiting to see if you can spot...
Very good. Recommend the self guided walk if you're up to. Just have to get out of synch with the bus tour which drops a bus load into your peaceful enjoyment of the animals.
Lots of animals to see, but be prepared to do a lot of walking. Surrounded by the beauty of nature. There's a cute gift shop too.

We enjoyed the two hour minibus ride around this preserve with our informative guide. It was great! We saw male and female moose, elk, deer, mountain goats, bison, eagle, white fox, sheep and lynx (only the caribou were hiding). You can do the organised tour which we enjoyed for some information on the animals, or you can walk or bike...
We went through the reserve as an add on to our tour. Scottie the frenchman was an excellent guide and the park it's self is just lovely. Well worth a visit.
Its a long walk but worth the effort to see all the rescued animals they have. Some are quite timid and not able to see.

We checked out the reserve on one of our days in Whitehorse at the end of our canoe trip. Nice place to spend a couple hours, saw lots of animals and very few people. No crowds, no rush.Nice to see animals were well cared for and had lots of space in a natural as possible setting.

Wasn't sure if my teens would like this since it's kinda like a zoo. However, they really enjoyed walking around the Reserve and reading the signs. Got a little lost because we misread the map but that was half the fun.

We walked the circuit and saw all the animals except for the lynx. It was probably napping as we were there mid-afternoon. The information panels are very informative. You can get excellent views of all animals. If you choose to walk you will be provided with a map of the preserve. The only thing to note for those thinking of...

Within walking distance of the Takhini Hot Springs campground. We took a walk to, and through, most of the preserve and saw many families walking as well. Staff were feeding some of the animals so had a chance to talk to one of them. (Would you believe that orange rinds make up a good part of the diet of the...
Take the bus tour, it takes about 1 1/2 hrs. The driver stops at all animal enclosures and shares a lot of information about each species.
This was a great collection of Yukon animals. No preditors, but foxes, lynx, goats, sheep, caribou, elk, deer and moose plus bison. Worth the time.
Bring a picnic and make an afternoon of it. We walked the grounds and really enjoyed ourselves - it was very relaxing.

This Wildlife Preserve is very well maintained and the tour is very informative about local wildlife. Walking the trail gives one the opportunity to enjoy a beautiful nature walk while visiting the animals. The bus tour, especially in winter when the weather conditions are not conducive to a long walk, is very informative and the drivers are very knowledgeable.Overall...

We chose to have take the bus tour around the facility, and we're glad we did. We stopped at each enclosure, and our nice tour guide was very knowledgeable, and answered our questions about the animals.

This 750 acre preserve is well laid out and well run in a beautiful setting. The wildlife is in large pastures surrounded by high, coarse mesh fencing that you can stick a camera lens through. During our two hour van tour we saw elk, mule deer, lynx, artic fox and moose. The preserve also has a rehabilitation unit that is...

What a great way to spend a couple of hours. We went on a bus tour with a really good guide. It was great to see these northern animals up close and to hear in detail about their natural environment. An amazing way to learn more about the northern mammals of the Yukon.

I went there with a friend and did the self-guided tour and we walked the 5km. It was fabulous. While some of the animals were further away it was still amazing to see them in person. The $15 fee to get in was well worth it. The services that are provided to the animals are great. Well worth going with...

We took the guided bus tour which is the best choice for hot days or older individuals. Our guide was very good and she provided lots of great information and pointed out animals that we might have missed otherwise. Very informative and good for all ages!

Fabulous low-key way to spend a few hours! There is a bus tour option, but if you have kids with excess energy, or want just a stroll -- skip the bus! It's a lovely walk. There's a loop at the back that goes up a hill -- we didn't see much from up there, so I would recommend skipping this...

The Yukon Wildlife Preserve is on Takhini Road, north of Whitehorse. I think it cost us between $15-20 per person. This is a family run preserve. All the species of animals have several acres each. They had a little shop where you bought tickets and where you could buy a few souvenirs. Inside that shop, they had a number of...

We took the bus tour. The guide was nice and friendly, but -- initially at least -- sounded like she's reciting a memorized text, rather than speaking on her own. Bring binoculars: the animals are sometimes at a fair distance. There are many kinds of deer and elk; there are also bison, mountain goats, arctic fox, and -- if you're...

We visited Skagway on a cruise and rented a car for the day. We were able to drive each way to Yukon Wildlife Perserve in less than three hours, including some delays for highway work. We combined it with a meal in Whitehorse and a little bit of sightseeing in Skagway for a very nice day that was significantly cheaper...

The Yukon Wildlife Preserve allows visitors to observe and photograph animals close up in their natural environment. The animals live in large, open enclosures to replicate their natural feeding and roaming grounds. Some of the animals found at the Yukon Wildlife Preserve are: musk ox, caribou, moose, arctic fox, lynx, thin horn sheep, mountain goats and deer. Our tour drove...

Although our tour group showed up a little late, Lindsay gave us a fantastic tour, answering all our questions and spending lots of times with animals we hadn't yet seen.If you're spending a couple of weeks in the Yukon, I think you should leave the Preserve to the end, once you've had some wildlife experiences of your own.The...

Booked as part of HAL land/cruise tour.Picked up on time from hotel and only 8 of us on the tour which allowed all questions to be fielded.Driver/guide good and very knowledgeable - met at the Preserve by Julia who was also very good at explaining and showing us around. I suppose we were in the preserve for just...

Was very informative and you could get close and take pictures. Check before you go to see when the animals loose their antlers. I really wanted to see a moose with them but they shed.... Worth a visit to learn about all the local animals! Loved the prairie dogs and hares!

We visit the Yukon Wildlife Preserve every time we visit Whitehorse. We don't take the bus tour, rather we prefer to walk and spend as much time as we need. Since we have small children it means we don't get to see all the animals, but we don't mind. The Preserve has an impressive array of animals and the kids...

Excellent. Wide range of Arctic animals. Scientists doing work while you are there. Animal enclosures beautifully kept and very very large so they seem to have lots of room to roam - it's not like a zoo. You might not see the animals if they are 'up the back'. Get there early (opens at 0930) as by 1130 it was...

The area is approximately 800 acres. We drove around 400 of them. Saw Muskox, Caribou, Sheep, Foxes, and many other animals of the north. We were on a time table unfortunately and only had an hour. Well worth a visit.
Lots of Yukon creatures. Handy bus for those not able to walk. Possible to view rehabilitation unit at specific times. Staff - friendly and knowledgeable.

I came on my honeymoon and decided to walk around instead of the bus tour which cost more. Wear good shoes and bring binoculars because the enclosures are quite open and you may not see much. Loop is around 5km.

It's not that easy to spot wildlife from the road, so if you are interested in seeing local Yukon wildlife, visit the Yukon Wildlife Preserve. The animals are in a very large area which is their natural habitat. You can walk around to see the different animals (caribou, moose, Dall sheep, elk, etc) or take a bus (provided on the...
Awesome animals and information! Definitely recommend this experience to everyone who comes out this way!

We had an amazing time! Our tour consisted of a pick up at home, van to the preserve and then the same van to the Takhini hot springs. We had an informative bus tour around the preserve. Our driver stopped at every animal enclosure and provided lots of information. We were lucky to see all of the animals, even the...

We went in the afternoon for the 4pm bus tour of the wildlife preserve. Our driver was very knowledgable and shared some great stories with us about all of the animals. He made sure that we had enough time at each of the sections of the park so that we could get our pictures. Definitely worth the trip out.
I was very happy to go there,Yukon Wildlife Preserve it's a beautiful place to see,all the animals it's quite and peace....you can take some nice pictures in souvenir....(January 2010)

We had a delightful time on the bus tour. Our leader shared a lot of info. and calmly answered the many questions our children had. We saw all the animals except for the Lynx and the red fox! Worth the visit.
My Dad and I have seen this on TV watching Dr. Oakly and was a must see when we came to Whitehorse. We missed the bus so walked around the enclosures and was impressed on how much room animals had..

We signed up for the bus tour which we think is the best way to see all the wild animals in the preserve. There are 13 species in the preserve. Elk, Caribou, Moose, Red Fox, Mule Deer, Artic Fox, Minx, and Muskox are just a few. The bus tour last about 1 hour and 45 minutes. Our guide was excellent...

I recently moved from BC and I've got to say that the Yukon Wildlife Preserve is probably my fave " go to" place in Whitehorse! I love the fact that the animals that are showcased there are all native species to the Yukon and are housed in amazing enclosures. You can totally tell that the animals are well cared for....

Unfortunately it was raining significantly on the day we visited the preserve. We were the only ones on the bus -- which meant we got a personalized commentary! We enjoyed the morning, seeing and photographing the animals. We did see some that are often hiding when it's warm and dry but missed others.

We spent about 3.5 hours walking the entire site (6.25 km with our going back and forth in some areas since the animals were so close). Taking in the wonderful views of the magnificent animals and surrounding hills was a great experience.Lucky enough to have two moose right next to us near the fence line and other animals close...

Really it's just a zoo where you may or may not see animals. I walked it, which at least made it last a while. It is very expensive for what it is. The people were very nice, but really there isn't anything in there you can't see on a drive to get to whitehorse.

You can likely walk or bike the entire preserve in about an hour if you don't stop too long to look at animals.They also offer bus tours every two hours, however I kept pace with the bus by walking so not sure if the extra $7 is worth it.I would recommend going earlier in the day while it's...

The Yukon wildlife preserve was highly promoted. It was easy to find and we found all the animals even in the rain. The cost was a bit high. $44 for two people $30 if we would've walked it is a long way and when I've taken several hours to walk. The narrator and bus driver Julia was really good and...
Took the tour conducted by tourist guides. Very informative and knowledgeable. Would suggest going to McBride museum first.

We had a fantastic afternoon walking leisurely around the park. The animal enclosures are wonderful, vast areas, we everything that the animals would have in the wild.It's a great place to take a picnic, relax and let the world pass bye - and spit some wonderful animals in enclosures, and also the wildlife on the park too - great...

Took a late afternoon bus tour of the Wildlife Preserve and although it was quite warm, we saw almost every type of animal they have. (You can also walk the Preserve as well.) The staff were very pleasant and our driver, Pete, was extremely knowledgeable on the animals at the Preserve and Yukon wildlife in general. Good to know they...

The Wildlife Preserve is a must-see. You can take a small bus or can walk. The wildlife include moose, caribou, musk ox, lynx, sheep, goats, eagles, arctic fox, and many others. We walked and spent about 4 hours there just enjoying the walk and taking LOTS of pictures.

This place was pretty magical. We saw almost all of the animals and were there for less than an hour (had to cut our visit short to catch a flight). Elk (and calves), buffalo (and calves), thin horned sheep, musk ox, mountain goats, lynx, arctic hare, arctic fox (and pups), moose, and the mule dear. Feels like you're walking around...

We visited the Preserve on a bus tour from Whitehorse. Upon entering the grounds a guide joined us on the bus and offered a great commentary as we travelled to each exhibit. Bear in mind that this is a huge open range reserve and not all aminals may be visible. We were fortunate in that all animals, apart from the...
Took about 1.5 hours to walk through the entire park. Seeing the animals is neat and they're well taken care of, but seeing them in the wild is always better (if you're lucky enough)

The Preserve is about a 20 minute drive out of Whitehorse. We got there just after ten, and so missed the shuttle which was a good thing. It made us walk the approximately 5K road route past the habitats of the animals. We walked at a leisurely pace, taking pictures as we went. In the first habitat, we saw Rocky...

Took the bus tour for $20 (senior) rate. Guide was very knowledgeable and stopped at every opportunity to view the animals. Elk are close to building, rest are on the 700 fenced acres of the preserve. Musk ox, bison, white fox, lynx, mountain goats, big horn sheep, deer, bald eagle, snowy owl, moose. I particulary liked the advice on where...

We saw all of the Yukon animals that were listed. A porcupine decided that he wanted to come in and visit also. We even got to see the elusive moose and mountain goats up close. We walked and thoroughly enjoyed the day. I even got a picture of a bluebird. Great way to spent a day with friends, family and...
I love this place (often seen on television on the Yukon Doctor show) There are two kinds of mountain goats, sheep, moose, bison, muskox, fox, lynx (and kits), and more. Walk, bike or ride the bus.

Guaranteed wildlife sightings abound in this preserve. We took the preserve touring bus to go around the property as it was misty rain out. Guide/driver Maureen was totally in her element in her narration of every species seen along the way. Totally worth the short drive out of Whitehorse to observe and admire elk, wood bison, moose, linx, deer, mountain...
Walk took a couple hours and we did see most of the animals...some huge enclosures that sometimes makes it challenging to see the animals. Well worth supporting.

The walk through the Preserve makes it possible to see many of the wild animals that would not be seen while traveling on the highways of the Yukon. It is advisable to take binoculars with you as some of the animals may be difficult to see with the naked eye because of the distance from you. There is a large...

This excellent facility allows visitors to view Yukon's large and small wildlife in their natural environment. The staff are knowledgeable and helpful. The location is out of town, so transport, either by car or a tour from Whitehorse is essential. The tours are pricey but includes a soak at the nearby Tahkini Hot Springs. We took the bus tour and thought it was well worth the money. Walking would be difficult as the place is huge.Our tour guide was knowledgable and passionate. As a local, I love visiting the Wildlife Preserve any time during the year. It's a great place to view the animals, get some exercise and support rehabilitation of various animals. A great place to bring visitors too.
In Whitehorse our wildlife preseve is really living on the wild side. They have lot's of wild animals! But be careful your on the wild side. But it's great for family and friends too.
Not a zoo. big areas for the wildlife. But still good viewing. Lots of walking but that is another reason to visit.

We took the bus tour and it was well worth it. We really enjoyed this tour, very informative and loads to see. A must do if you are in the area. Loved the moose!

We hired a tour with Northern Tales and it was great. On Wednesdays the Preserve is closed, but they have a permit and we had the Preserve almost for ourselves. It was great. Wouldn't normally get excited about a game preserve and actually was a bit underwhelmed......until I got there! What an amazing place doing amazing things. After a tiring three days of travel, long nights viewing the Aurora Borealis, and a dog-sledding excursion, this was a welcome jaunt. We enjoy a lot visiting this place, the explanations were very interesting and the care to rehabilitate the wild animals in the most likely their own enviroment, is the best.
It was a cold and clear day and we thoroughly enjoyed seeing the various animals. Our guide was extremely knowledgeable and made the trip very worth while.

Did the tour on the bus and the guide was a wildlife biologist and conservation worker. We learned so much about the animals and Yukon's efforts to conserve the wilderness. It was a freezing cold day but we still had great time, very interesting to lean about the animals & the rescues. Rode around in the mini bus but if the weather is fine it would be great to walk

Great wildlife viewing in as natural a setting as one can make it. You can take a guided small bus tour or a self-guided walking tour or do as we did on cross-country skis. It's a great way to spend an afternoon
We went on tour of Yukon Wildlife Preserve. Lots of different animals you would not see at normal wildlife park. Reindeer, Moose, Artic Fox, Mountain Goat.
We njoyed our tour through the park, seeing the animals in their natural habitat. Best one was the Artic Fox.
Make sure to walk the entire trail, it's worth it. We didn't take the shuttle bus. Great photo opportunities.

YWR is a beautiful gem tucked in the picturesque hills of Yukon. We attended this with the primary aim of seeing moose and were not disappointed. The park is vast and there is a 5km walking/skiing loop or you can take a bus tour. Awesome place where local animals have plentyof space to roam their habitat and you can take good pictures and have a great leisure time ifyou just want to observe, always worthwhile a return visit

We took the guided bus tour and learned much about some of the animals that inhabit northern Canada. Our children had been studying animal adaptions at school and were able to see for themselves the adaptions needed to live in the cold.

Great place to visit to see all sorts of wildlife in Yukon. You can walk around and view the animals in natural habitat and not in cages like a zoo. They have moose elk fox and even mountain sheep. They also help with those animals that need to be rehabilitation. Great people with s great cause.

Great 2 hour visit to this Preserve. Well maintained, with easy access around the grounds. We have been two times, once on our own, and the second as part of the guided bus tour. We took the guided bus tour. The guide was very knowledgeable about both the type of animal in general and the specific animal we were viewing. I was not particularly keen on going at first, but I am glad I went.
Really nice for a day with the family, walk around and see some animals! I think the walking loop is about 5 km??

This was a great place to visit. We saw every animal there since it was unseasonable warm when we visited. A Lynx, red fox, snow fox, elk, deer, moose, sheep, so many you cannot name them all. Tour guide very knowledgeable

We visit the wildlife preserve a few times of year. The animals all have nice big pens with lots of room to roam around, and close to natural habitats. The staff are always really great, friendly and helpful. My young children always enjoy seeing the animals.

We do a fair amount of nature touring. Coming from Caslifornia, we got to see several species we hadn't seen before; Lynx, Musk Ox, Arctic Fox, and Wood Bison. Went to the preserve and saw many animals only previously seen on TV. Loved the arctic fox, bison and caribou. Bus ride around was definitely preferable to walking.

Terrific bubbly tour guide who had lots of info about the beautiful animals. Breathtaking scenery, great up-close interaction and interesting information.

I recommend this visit to all. We were very fortunate to visit the rehab area which is normally not opened. The comments provided by our guide enriched our visit.Winter time is great to go around the park.

I went to the wildlife reserve as part of a tour by Northern Tales at the start of winter. We hopped on the bus with a lovely guide who told us the stories and names of the animals in the rescue sanctuary. Gorgeous wildlife - an eye opener.
Very nice to see the animals into the wild! As I'm biologist, I loved to see many different species that I have never seen before. The owners was so gentle!
it is an amazing walk at any time of the year. Spring is great because of all the young. I think everyone that comes to the Yukon take a walk here.

I took the grandsons 4 and 2 years. They both had a great time. I reccomend taking the bus tour because you learn so much about the animals. The preserve is a nice place to see the animals you missed while driving the Dempster. You can walk the loop or take a tour bus. We walked and found it to be pleasant and allowed us to spend as much time as we liked at the different animals that interested us.
Amazing place! If you dont get to see wildlife in the wild! this is the next best thing! The guided bus tour is wonderful! and they really take care of you and the animals so well!

Nice, very large enclosures for the animals, while still allowing (for the most part) for good photos to be taken. A good amount of walking is required (approximately 5KM), so wear decent shoes. An interesting way to spend a couple hours.

this is a large place, somewhat zoo like, with paddocks with many different animals, from muskox to deer and much more

I visited this awesome place with my adult children that live in Whitehorse. All of the animals have huge and well kept pens. I was impressed with how well the animals look. Good way to see Yukon wildlife and good exercise if you choose to walk like I did. I was contented and thought it was worth it.
Kids enjoyed seeing different animals - we're from Ontario. Seemed a bit expensive? Be prepared to walk unless you pay extra to take the bus tour. The North has some stunning and majestic animals.

What a treat! Seeing the muskoxen chilling. Very informative guide who provided detail information regarding the animals kept at the wildlife preserve. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to the Yukon Wildlife Preserve. We opted to walk, rather than do the tour. It was great. We had two pre-teen boys with us and they were really engaged. The preserve is NOT like a zoo, really pleasing enclosures with natural settings.

Love the Preserve. Staff are friendly and there are so many different animals to see in very natural habitat.

We went to the Wildlife Preserve on a experiential day for the class. Have to say that the staff were brilliant. Activities were appropriate for the age group and the students were kept engaged for pretty much the whole day. Quite an achievement for that class. Will certainly return in the future.

This attraction has a variety of animals -mostly the grazers, but there are also lynx and foxes. I have been to the Wildlife Preserve several times this year, at different times of the year. It is simply a spectacular place to visit: interesting and informative and eye-opening. It helps to book one of the van trips through the preserve, including a guide. These offer excellent value.

I live in the Yukon. I've seen most of these animals in the bush. Still, the preserve is gorgeous and a lot of fun. Being able to safely see the animals up close is a blast. This isn't your regular zoo. You get to see the animals up close and personal here. If you've never seen the animal of the north, then this is the perfect place to see all of them at the same time. The animals were well taken care of. They were easy to view. It is always nice to see wild animals in a preserve being taken care of so well. I would visit again.

I decided to go visit the preserve as a nice way to spend the afternoon. I loved visiting the area and seeing the unique animals of the region in quiet and gentle areas. The views were lovely over the hills and the variety of animals available to view was fantastic. A great experience for any animal lover.

Got a good up close look at the animals and good information about them from the guide. The tour was about 2 hours long and the guide was very flexible in the time we spent looking at all the wildlife.
